<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_thread_:
```c
int
MHD_create_thread_ (MHD_thread_handle_ID_ *handle_id,
                    size_t stack_size,
                    MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ start_routine,
                    void *arg)
{
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  int res;
#if defined(MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_)
  pthread_t *const new_tid_ptr =
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ (handle_id);
#else  /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ */
  pthread_t new_tid;
  pthread_t *const new_tid_ptr = &new_tid;
#endif /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ */

  mhd_assert (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (*handle_id));

  if (0 != stack_size)
  {
    pthread_attr_t attr;
    res = pthread_attr_init (&attr);
    if (0 == res)
    {
      res = pthread_attr_setstacksize (&attr,
                                       stack_size);
      if (0 == res)
        res = pthread_create (new_tid_ptr,
                              &attr,
                              start_routine,
                              arg);
      pthread_attr_destroy (&attr);
    }
  }
  else
    res = pthread_create (new_tid_ptr,
                          NULL,
                          start_routine,
                          arg);

  if (0 != res)
  {
    errno = res;
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_invalid_ (handle_id);
  }
#if ! defined(MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_)
  else
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_ (handle_id, new_tid);
#endif /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_current_thread_ID_ */

  return ! res;
#elif defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  uintptr_t thr_handle;
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T != SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_INT

  mhd_assert (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (*handle_id));

  if (stack_size > UINT_MAX)
  {
    errno = EINVAL;
    return 0;
  }
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T != SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_INT */
  thr_handle = (uintptr_t) _beginthreadex (NULL,
                                           (unsigned int) stack_size,
                                           start_routine,
                                           arg,
                                           0,
                                           NULL);
  if ((MHD_thread_handle_native_) 0 == (MHD_thread_handle_native_) thr_handle)
    return 0;

  MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_ (handle_id, \
                                           (MHD_thread_handle_native_) \
                                           thr_handle);

  return ! 0;
#endif
}
```

explanation: I selected the code fragments that introduce or propagate pointer-typed parameters/objects (the function parameters and the places where pointer values are obtained, passed to thread APIs, or stored/updated via the thread-handle macros). Other parts of the function do not need investigation for Rule 8.13 because they do not present opportunities for adding a const qualifier to the pointed-to type: - Local non-pointer variables and integer checks (e.g. res, stack_size comparisons, thr_handle) are not applicable. - The pthread_attr_t object is modified by the attr API calls (init/setstacksize/destroy); those APIs require a non-const pointer to allow mutation, so const qualification of the pointee is not appropriate. - The code uses platform APIs (pthread_create, _beginthreadex and related thread-handle macros) whose parameter types dictate the pointee mutability; those API arguments either must be writable (so cannot be const) or are function-pointer/void-pointer callbacks dictated by the API. - Assertions, errno assignments and control-flow constructs do not involve pointer-to-data constness. - Macro wrappers that set or invalidate the thread handle perform mutations through the provided pointer, so the pointee cannot be const. Therefore the remaining fragments are either unrelated to pointer constness or intentionally require non-const pointees and need not be investigated further for Rule 8.13.
